title: Sataf
text:
Sataf (<a href="Arabic">Arabic</a>: صطاف, <a href="Hebrew">Hebrew</a>: סטף) was a <a href="Palestinians">Palestinian</a> village in the <a href="Jerusalem%20Subdistrict%2C%20Mandatory%20Palestine">Jerusalem Subdistrict</a> depopulated during the <a href="1948%20Arab%E2%80%93Israeli%20War">1948 Arab–Israeli War</a>. It was located 10 km west of <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>, with <a href="Nahal%20Sorek">Sorek Valley</a> (Arabic: Wadi as-Sarar) bordering to the east.
Two springs, Ein Sataf and Ein Bikura flow from the site into the riverbed below.
A monastery located across the valley from Sataf, i.e. south of Wadi as-Sarar, known by local Arabs as Ein el-Habis (the "Spring of the Hermitage"), is officially called <a href="Monastery%20of%20Saint%20John%20in%20the%20Wilderness">Monastery of Saint John in the Wilderness</a>.
Today it is a tourist site showcasing ancient agricultural techniques used in the Jerusalem Mountains.
History.
Chalcolithic period.
Remains of a 4,000 BCE <a href="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a> village were discovered at the site. The related traces of agricultural activities number among the oldest in the region.
Byzantine period.
Most ancient remains date to the <a href="Byzantine%20Empire">Byzantine period</a>.
Mamluk period.
The first written mention of the site is from the <a href="Mamluk%20Sultanate%20%28Cairo%29">Mamluk</a> era.
Ottoman period.
Sataf was noted in the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> <a href="daftar">tax records</a> of 1525-1526 and 1538–1539, as being located in the <a href="Sanjak">Sanjak</a> of <a href="Al-Quds">Al-Quds</a>. According to archaeological work, the village originated in the late 16th century, with the use of several cave−dwellings. Later, houses were erected in front of the caves.
In 1838 it was described as a <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a> village, located in the "Beni Hasan" district, west of Jerusalem.
In 1863, <a href="Victor%20Gu%C3%A9rin">Victor Guérin</a> found a village of one hundred and eighty people. He further noted that their houses were standing on the slopes of a mountain, and that the mountainside was covered by successive terraces. An Ottoman village list from about 1870 counted 38 houses and a population of 115, whereby only men were counted.
In 1883, the <a href="Palestine%20Exploration%20Fund">Palestine Exploration Fund</a>'s <a href="Survey%20of%20Western%20Palestine">Survey of Western Palestine</a> described "Setaf" as "a village of moderate size, of stone houses, perched on the steep side of a valley. It has a spring lower down, on the north."
In 1896 the population of Sataf was estimated to be about 180 persons.
British Mandate period.
By the <a href="1922%20census%20of%20Palestine">1922 census of Palestine</a> conducted by the <a href="Mandatory%20Palestine">British Mandate authorities</a>, Sataf had a population of 329; 321 Muslims and 8 Christians. All the Christians were Roman Catholic. The <a href="1931%20census%20of%20Palestine">1931 census</a> lists 381 inhabitants; 379 Muslim and 2 Christian, in a total of 101 houses.
In the <a href="Village%20Statistics%2C%201945">1945 statistics</a> the population of Sataf was 540, all Muslims, and the total land area was 3,775 <a href="dunam">dunam</a>s, according to an official land and population survey. Of this, 928 dunams were plantations and irrigable land, 465 for cereals, while 22 dunams were built-up land.
1948, aftermath.
On July 13–14, 1948 the Arab village was depopulated by the <a href="Har%27el%20Brigade">Har'el Brigade</a>, during <a href="Operation%20Danny">Operation Danny</a>.
Sataf and the surrounding area became part of the newly created State of <a href="Israel">Israel</a>. A short time after the 1948 War, a small group of Jewish immigrants from North Africa settled for a few months in the village area. Subsequently, the <a href="Israel%20Defence%20Forces">IDF's</a> <a href="Unit%20101">Unit 101</a> and <a href="Paratroopers%20Brigade">paratroopers</a> used it for training purposes.
In the 1980s the <a href="Jewish%20National%20Fund">Jewish National Fund</a> began the restoration of ancient agricultural <a href="Terrace%20%28agriculture%29">terraces</a>, and the area around the springs has been turned into a tourist site. A forest around the site was also planted by the Jewish National Fund.
In 1992, Sataf was described as follows: "Many half-destroyed walls still stand, and some still have <a href="arch">arch</a>ed doorways. The walls of a few houses with collapsed roofs are almost intact...The area around the village spring, which is located to the east next to the ruins of a rectangular stone house, has been turned into an Israeli tourist site. A Jewish family has settled on the west side of the village, and have fenced in some of the village area."
Shrine of 'Ubayd.
The shrine (<a href="Maqam%20%28shrine%29">maqam</a>) of 'Ubayd, southwest of the village site, contains a courtyard and three rooms. According to <a href="Tawfiq%20Canaan">Tawfiq Canaan</a>, <a href="Sheikh">Sheikh</a> 'Ubayd "is said to kill any goat or sheep who enters his cave."
